message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Challenges in Building Intelligent Open-domain Dialog Systems
Paper Abstract: There is a resurgent interest in developing intelligent open-domain dialog systems due to the availability of large amounts of conversational data and the recent progress on neural approaches to conversational AI [33]. Unlike traditional task-oriented bots, an open-domain dialog system aims to establish long-term connections with users by satisfying the human need for communication, affection, and social belonging. This article reviews the recent work on neural approaches that are devoted to addressing three challenges in developing such systems: semantics , consistency , and interactiveness . Semantics requires a dialog system to not only understand the content of the dialog but also identify users’ emotional and social needs during the conversation. Consistency requires the system to demonstrate a consistent personality to win users’ trust and gain their long-term confidence. Interactiveness refers to the system’s ability to generate interpersonal responses to achieve particular social goals such as entertainment and conforming. The studies we select to present in this survey are based on our unique views and are by no means complete. Nevertheless, we hope that the discussion will inspire new research in developing more intelligent open-domain dialog systems.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Neural network (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network"},{"title":"Neural network (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(biology)"},{"title":"History of artificial neural networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_artificial_neural_networks"},{"title":"Graph neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_neural_network"},{"title":"Energy-based generative neural network","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy-based_generative_neural_network"},{"title":"Physical neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_neural_network"},{"title":"Convolutional neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolutional_neural_network"},{"title":"Mathematics of neural networks in machine learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematics_of_neural_networks_in_machine_learning"},{"title":"Feedback neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_neural_network"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of neural networks:

## What Are Neural Networks?

A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.(no content)In machine learning, a neural network is an artificial mathematical model used to approximate nonlinear functions.

## Structure

Signals travel from the first layer (the input layer) to the last layer (the output layer), possibly passing through multiple intermediate layers (hidden layers).(no content)A network is typically called a deep neural network if it has at least two hidden layers.

## Applications

Neural networks are used to solve problems in artificial intelligence, and have thereby found applications in many disciplines, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, facial recognition, handwriting recognition, general game playing, and generative AI.

## Training

Neural networks are typically trained through empirical risk minimization, which is based on the idea of optimizing the network's parameters to minimize the difference, or empirical risk, between the predicted output and the actual target values in a given dataset.(no content)Gradient-based methods such as backpropagation are usually used to estimate the parameters of the network.

## Historical Background

Today's deep neural networks are based on early work in statistics over 200 years ago.(no content)In 1958, psychologist Frank Rosenblatt described the perceptron, one of the first implemented artificial neural networks, funded by the United States Office of Naval Research.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "semantic analysis NLP"

Links: [{"title":"Latent semantic analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latent_semantic_analysis"},{"title":"Semantic analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_analysis"},{"title":"Semantic analysis (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_analysis_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Semantic analysis (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_analysis_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Semantic network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_network"},{"title":"Natural language processing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_processing"},{"title":"Semantic decomposition (natural language processing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_decomposition_(natural_language_processing)"},{"title":"Apache cTAKES - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apache_cTAKES"},{"title":"Scott Deerwester - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Deerwester"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of semantic analysis in NLP:

## Definition

In linguistics, semantic analysis is the process of relating syntactic structures, from the levels of words, phrases, clauses, sentences and paragraphs to the level of the writing as a whole, to their language-independent meanings.(no content)In machine learning, semantic analysis of a text corpus is the task of building structures that approximate concepts from a large set of documents, and it generally does not involve prior semantic understanding of the documents.

## Key Techniques

One prominent approach is **Latent Semantic Analysis (LSA)**: Latent semantic analysis is a technique in natural language processing, in particular distributional semantics, of analyzing relationships between a set of documents and the terms they contain by producing a set of concepts related to the documents and terms.(no content)LSA is based on the principle that words that are used in the same contexts tend to have similar meanings, and a key feature of LSI is its ability to extract the conceptual content of a body of text by establishing associations between those terms that occur in similar contexts.

## Related NLP Tasks

Semantic analysis includes aspects of several elementary NLP tasks from semantics such as semantic role labelling and word-sense disambiguation.(no content)Semantic networks are used in natural language processing applications such as semantic parsing and word-sense disambiguation.

## Applications

LSA is used in natural language processing applications, including chatbots and automatic translation services, and has found applications in data mining, recommender systems, and business intelligence tools.

Web search results for query: "emotion recognition"

Links: [{"title":"Emotion recognition in conversation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotion_recognition_in_conversation"},{"title":"Emotion recognition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotion_recognition"},{"title":"List of facial expression databases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facial_expression_databases"},{"title":"Affective computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affective_computing"},{"title":"Object recognition (cognitive science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_object_recognition_(animal_test)"},{"title":"OpenSMILE - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenSMILE"},{"title":"Facial expression - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facial_expression"},{"title":"Reverence (emotion) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reverence_(emotion)"},{"title":"Face - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_faces"},{"title":"Affectiva - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affectiva"}]

I've found comprehensive information about emotion recognition. Here's a summary of what I found:

## Overview

Emotion recognition is the process of identifying human emotion.(no content)Use of technology to help people with emotion recognition is a relatively nascent research area, with technology generally working best if it uses multiple modalities in context.

## Methods and Approaches

The most work has been conducted on automating the recognition of facial expressions from video, spoken expressions from audio, written expressions from text, and physiology as measured by wearables.(no content)The accuracy of emotion recognition is usually improved when it combines the analysis of human expressions from multimodal forms such as texts, physiology, audio, or video.

## Technical Approaches

There is now an extensive literature proposing and evaluating hundreds of different kinds of methods, leveraging techniques from multiple areas, such as signal processing, machine learning, computer vision, and speech processing.(no content)The existing approaches in emotion recognition can be generally classified into three main categories: knowledge-based techniques, statistical methods, and hybrid approaches. Knowledge-based techniques utilize domain knowledge and the semantic and syntactic characteristics of text and potentially spoken language.

## Subfields

Emotion recognition in conversation (ERC) is a sub-field of emotion recognition that focuses on mining human emotions from conversations or dialogues having two or more interlocutors.

## Related Field

Affective computing is the study and development of systems and devices that can recognize, interpret, process, and simulate human affects. It is an interdisciplinary field spanning computer science, psychology, and cognitive science.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## Definition and Overview

A dialogue system, or conversational agent (CA), is a computer system intended to converse with a human.(no content)Dialogue systems employed one or more of text, speech, graphics, haptics, gestures, and other modes for communication on both the input and output channel.

## Core Components

Principal to any dialogue system is the dialogue manager, which is a component that manages the state of the dialogue, and dialogue strategy.(no content)The semantic information is analysed by the dialogue manager, which keeps the history and state of the dialogue and manages the general flow of the conversation.

## Types: Spoken Dialog Systems

A spoken dialog system (SDS) is a computer system able to converse with a human with voice.(no content)It has two essential components that do not exist in a written text dialog system: a speech recognizer and a text-to-speech module.

## Modern Development

In the 2020s, dialogue systems have increasingly been built on top of large language models (LLMs), which allow them to handle open-domain conversation more flexibly than earlier rule-based or statistical approaches.

## Applications

Dialogue systems can support a broad range of applications in business enterprises, education, government, healthcare, and entertainment.(no content)Simple dialogue systems are widely used to decrease the human workload in call centers. In this and other industrial telephony applications, the functionality provided by dialogue systems is known as interactive voice response or IVR.

Links: [{"title":"Chatbot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chatbot"},{"title":"Conversational user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conversational_user_interface"},{"title":"Conversational commerce - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conversational_commerce"},{"title":"Conversable - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conversable"},{"title":"ChatGPT - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ChatGPT"},{"title":"List of chatbots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_chatbots"},{"title":"Gupshup - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gupshup"},{"title":"Jabberwacky - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jabberwacky"},{"title":"Amelia (company) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amelia_(company)"},{"title":"Conversica - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conversica"}]

Here's what I found about conversational AI:

## Definition

A conversational user interface (CUI) is a user interface for computers that emulates a conversation with a human.(no content)Modern chatbots are typically online and use generative artificial intelligence systems that are capable of maintaining a conversation with a user in natural language and simulating the way a human would behave as a conversational partner.

## Technology

Conversational interfaces use natural language processing (NLP) to allow computers to understand, analyze, and create meaning from human language.(no content)Such chatbots often use deep learning and natural language processing, but simpler chatbots have existed for decades.

## Types of Conversational AI

There are two main categories of conversational interfaces: voice assistants and chatbots. A voice user interface allows a user to complete an action by speaking a command.(no content)A chatbot is a web- or mobile-based interface that allows the user to ask questions and retrieve information. This information can be generic in nature such as the Google Assistant chat window that allows for internet searches, or it can be a specific brand or service which allows the user to gain information about the status of their various accounts.

## Business Applications

A major area where chatbots have long been used is customer service and support, with various sorts of virtual assistants.(no content)More frequently, companies are leveraging chatbots as a way to offload simple questions and transactions from human agents. These chatbots provide the option to assist a user, but then directly transfer the customer to a live agent within the same chat window if the conversation becomes too complex.

## Natural Language Processing (NLP)

Natural language processing (NLP) is the processing of natural language information by a computer and is a subfield of computer science closely associated with artificial intelligence.(no content)NLP is also related to information retrieval, knowledge representation, computational linguistics, and linguistics more broadly.

### Key Tasks

Major processing tasks in an NLP system include speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation.

### Historical Background

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s.(no content)Up until the 1980s, most natural language processing systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules, but starting in the late 1980s, there was a revolution in natural language processing with the introduction of machine learning algorithms for language processing.

### Recent Advances

The Transformer architecture was introduced in 2017, and the concept of large language models (LLM) emerged in late 2010s.(no content)In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced the capabilities of natural language processing, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s.(no content)Up until the 1980s, most natural language processing systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules, but starting in the late 1980s, there was a revolution in natural language processing with the introduction of machine learning algorithms for language processing.

### Recent Advances

The Transformer architecture was introduced in 2017, and the concept of large language models (LLM) emerged in late 2010s.(no content)In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced the capabilities of natural language processing, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

Here are the search results for "chatbot":

## Definition

A chatbot (originally chatterbot) is a software application or web interface designed to have textual or spoken conversations.(no content)Modern chatbots use generative artificial intelligence systems that are capable of maintaining a conversation with a user in natural language and simulating the way a human would behave as a conversational partner.

## Technology

Modern chatbots like ChatGPT are often based on large language models called generative pre-trained transformers (GPT), which are based on a deep learning architecture called the transformer containing artificial neural networks, and generate text after being trained on a large text corpus.

## Popularity

Chatbots have increased in popularity as part of the AI boom of the 2020s, including ChatGPT, followed by competitors such as Gemini, Claude and later Grok.

## Applications

A major area where chatbots have long been used is customer service and support, with various sorts of virtual assistants.(no content)Many banks, insurers, media companies, e-commerce companies, airlines, hotel chains, retailers, health care providers, government entities, and restaurant chains have used chatbots to answer simple questions, increase customer engagement, for promotion, and to offer additional ways to order from them.

The search results also provide information about specific modern chatbots like Gemini (formerly known as Bard), a generative artificial intelligence chatbot developed by Google that was launched on March 21, 2023, and DeepSeek-R1, which was released on 20 January 2025 and surpassed ChatGPT as the most downloaded freeware app on the iOS App Store in the United States by 27 January.

Links: [{"title":"Dialogue system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialogue_system"},{"title":"Dialog manager - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialog_manager"},{"title":"Task-based language teaching - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Task-based_language_learning"},{"title":"Spoken dialog system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spoken_dialog_system"},{"title":"Dialogue education - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialogue_education"},{"title":"Dialogue journal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialogue_journal"},{"title":"The Theory of Communicative Action - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Theory_of_Communicative_Action"},{"title":"Dialog box - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/About_box"},{"title":"Discourse-completion task - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discourse-completion_task"},{"title":"Dialogue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialogue"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about task-oriented dialogue:

## Overview

A dialogue system, or conversational agent (CA), is a computer system intended to converse with a human. Task-oriented dialogue refers specifically to dialogue systems designed to help users accomplish specific goals or complete particular tasks.

## Key Components and Features

A dialog manager (DM) is a component of a dialog system (DS), responsible for the state and flow of the conversation. In task-oriented systems, the dialogue manager contacts one or more task managers, that have knowledge of the specific task domain.(no content)Problem-solving dialog systems may allow human users to engage in a number of different activities that may include information access, plan construction and possible execution of the latter.

## Common Applications

Task-oriented dialogue systems support various practical uses, including:

- Weather, trains schedules, stock quotes, directory assistance
- Credit card and bank enquiries; ticket purchases
- Technical support including documentation access and diagnostic testing
- Education, such as physics or math, and language learning

## Modern Development

In the 2020s, dialogue systems have increasingly been built on top of large language models (LLMs), which allow them to handle open-domain conversation more flexibly than earlier rule-based or statistical approaches.
